During the last four years, a deterioration of the humanitarian situation has been observed in Colombia due to the expansion and re-configuration of a variety of non-state armed groups (NSAGs), the increase of climate variability-related disasters, the persistence of socioeconomic needs, and the limited institutional capacities to address both internally affected population as well as the mass influx of migrants and refugees. Therefore, the whole landmass is considered exposed to the complex crisis.

During the last four years, a deterioration of the humanitarian situation has been observed in Colombia due to the expansion and re-configuration of a variety of non-state armed groups (NSAGs), the increase of climate variability-related disasters, the persistence of socioeconomic needs, and the limited institutional capacities to address both internally affected population as well as the mass influx of migrants and refugees. Therefore, the whole population of Colombia are considered exposed to the complex crisis.

The number of people in needs in Colombia in 2023 according to the latest humanitarian needs overview. The number of people in needs are intersectoral. The needs are driven by exapansion and re-configuration of a variety of non-state armed groups (NSAGs), the increase of climate variability-related disasters, the persistence of socioeconomic needs, and the limited institutional capacities to address both internally affected population as well as the mass influx of migrants and refugees. Of these people, around 3.1 million are in acute need, while 394.000 have critical needs – the majority of whom live in rural areas.

Based on the 2023 HNO - PiN and severity figures were calculated through sectoral and inter-sectoral approach: 
The 2023 Inter-Sector Need Severity Classification: the severity is minimal 25%, stress 50%, severe 21%, extreme 3%, and catastrophic 1%. These rates were multiplied by the population of the West Bank of 3,200,000

Level 1 = Minimal = Exposed population – Affected population – PiN. The total population is considered facing at least minor humanitarian conditions. The entire population (about 3,200,000) is considered exposed 

Level 2 = Stress = Affected population – PiN. Almost all the population are affected

Level 3, 4, & 5 = Severe + Extreme + Catastrophic = PiN which is about 800,000 million

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. The People exposed figure represents the total population in the Gaza Strip who is classified in IPC Phase (1:5) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024.
Noone is placed in IPC phase 1 and therefore the number of people exposed is equal to people affected. The whole population of the Gaza strip is considered exposed to the conflict crisis.

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. The People affected figure represents the total population in the Gaza Strip who is classified in IPC Phase (2:5) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024.

The number is considered low reliabitlity as there many people are missing and/or under the rubbles and their status is not determined.

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. The PIN figure represents the total population in the Gaza Strip who is classified in IPC Phase 3 or above for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024.

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. According to the IPC analysis, there are no people facing None/Minimal food security level (IPC Phase 1) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024.

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. According to the IPC analysis, there are 2,500 people facing stressed food security level (IPC Phase 2) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024. ACAPS considers them to be in level 2 of the severity index (Stressed humanitarian conditions).

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. According to the IPC analysis, there are 477800 people facing crisis food security level (IPC Phase 3) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024. ACAPS considers them to be in level 3 of the severity index (Moderate humanitarian conditions).

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. According to the IPC analysis, there are 1169600 people facing emergency food security level (IPC Phase 4) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024. ACAPS considers them to be in level 4 of the severity index (Severe humanitarian conditions).

To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of the Gaza Strip. According to the IPC analysis, there are 576600 people facing Catastrophe/ Famine food security level (IPC Phase 5) for the projection period 8 December 2023 - 7 February 2024. ACAPS considers them to be in level 5 of the severity index (Extreme humanitarian conditions).

The figure represents the number of damaged buildings in the Gaza Strip as of 28 January 2024. The figure represents the number of destroyed buildings in the Gaza Strip. The figure includes the number of destroyed housing units and destroyed bakeries as of 28 January 2024. The figure is considered low reliabitlity as there is no full assessment has been conducted.

The total number of fatalities between 01 July 2023 and 26 January 2024

Only Refugees and asylum-seekers and Migrants are considered PiN. The total population of the Refugees, asylum-seekers and migrants are among the most marginalized and vulnerable groups in Yemen and are largely dependent on external humanitarian assistance to meet their basic needs. To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of Ma’rib as it is the most sever classification in Yemen and because similarity as Ma’rib sever humanitarian condition is partially driven by the huge IDPs whose humanitarian condition would more resemble the conditions of migrants relatively compared to host community.

Thus, the percentages of IPC Ph 5 and Ph 4 were used to multiply by the people affected to get L5, Ph3 to get L4, Ph2 at L3 while the remaining were placed in L3. This means 20% of affected were placed in L5, 35% in L4, and 25% in L3. 

This is a conservative under estimation as it only takes food security aspect in determining the humanitarian condition instead of a multi-sectorial humanitarian conditions.

Total population of the country according to 2024 humanitarian need overview. This number was adopted instead of World Bank figure, as they consider the population movement such internal displacement and people who are in transit seeking refuge in neighbouring counties and beyond.

Guatemala is experiencing a complex humanitarian crisis generated by overlapping shocks and impacts - both sudden and slow-onset, short- and long-term -. Therefore, the total landmass of the country is considered  exposed to the crisis.

Guatemala has undergone changes in the political, legal, institutional, security and governance landscape, it also experienced weather events. Therefore, the entire population living in Guatemala are considered exposed to the crisis.

According to OCHA's Humanitarian Needs Overview 2024, the five departments with the highest rates of food insecurity (IPC Phases 3 and 4) are Alta Verapaz, Huehuetenango, San Marcos, Quiché and Chiquimula; and the departments with highest people movement are Chiquimula, Guatemala, and San Marcos. The population of those departments are considered to be the people affected.

According to OCHA's Humanitarian Needs Overview for 2024, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) has monitored 105,000 people in transit between April and September 2023. The majority of displaced nationalities are Venezuela and Honduras, followed by others like Ecuador, Colombia, Haiti and some Asian.

The needs are driven by food and nutrition insecurity which has increased in certain regions. This crisis is caused not only by droughts, attributed to climate change, but also by other socioeconomic and political variables.
The number of people who are exposed to the crisis however not affected or in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance. There may be some needs but are not life-threatening.

The number of people who are affected by the crisis however not in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance. Needs are higher than level 1 but are still not life-threatening. The affected population can meet their needs by applying coping strategies.

They are part of people in needs and humanitarian assistance from various sectors are required.

Hondurans is highly vulnerable to the impacts of violence, migration, forced displacement, the climate crisis, as well as food and nutrition insecurity. The whole Honduras is exposed to different context of extreme fragility, econmoic, political and social conflicts. Therefore the whole country is considered exposed to the crisis and the total landmass of the country is taken.

HNRP 2024 does not provide the number of people exposed to different drivers of the complex crisis in Honduras. Hondurans are highly vulnerable to the impacts of violence, migration, forced displacement, the climate crisis, as well as food and nutrition insecurity. The whole of Honduras is exposed to different contexts of extreme fragility, and economic, political and social conflicts. Therefore the whole country is considered exposed to the crisis and the total population of the country is taken. 
The whole country matches as well the outcomes of the Integrated Phase Classification (IPC) June - August 2023 projection. The whole population are in IPC phase 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

HNRP 2024 does not provide the number of people affected by different drivers of the complex crisis in Honduras. Therefore, the Integrated Phase Classification (IPC) June - August 2023 projection has been considered to estimate the number of people affected by the crisis. The estimation can be made by taking the number of people in IPC phases 2, 3, 4, and 5 which is about 60% of the people live in the country. This number is the people who are affected by the crisis. However, this figure's reliability is low as food security is just one of the multiple drivers of this crisis besides violence and human mobility.

The total number of crisis-related displaced people is calculated with the number of internally displaced people in Honduras as a result of violence between 2004 and 2018 (247000) and the number of incoming refugees during 2023 according OCHA estimations (506.936)

The 2024 HNO highlights that Honduras continues to be vulnerable to the effects of at least four issues: i) food and nutrition insecurity; (ii) the impacts of generalized violence; (iii) forced displacement, mixed movements and return of Hondurans; (iv) and climate change and natural disasters. The HNO highlights that as a result of these, 2.8 million people are currently in humanitarian need, that is, 28% of the population.
The number of people who are exposed to the crisis however not affected or in needs of urgent humanitarian assistance. There may be some needs but are not life-threatening.

The number of people who are affected by the crisis however not in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. Needs are higher than level 1 but are still not life-threatening. The affected population can meet their needs by applying coping strategies.
